Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2008 06:04AM haykat57 wrote: txgrlo1, you're the one I want to talk to because I have been thinking about doing  a masectomy now that I have seen the results.  I was actually saying I wanted a masectomy until all 3 of my onco drs said lumpectomy should do.  But now I have to have radiation and I'm so uneven.  How long before you had the masectomy and did you still do radiation?
Posts.Title: lopsided haykat57 starzhere

Posts.Content: haykat57 wrote: Hi, I just had a lumpectomy on Friday and I am feeling very lopsided.  I was a 44c before surgery and my affected breast looks to be a sadly mis-shapen 36b now.  My surgeon spoke to my husband post-op and said she had to take a lot more than she had hoped, but that it should look alright with the right clothes.  I wear very lightweight clothing because of the heat here in south Texas and usually sleeveless.  I only own about two tops that are loose button down types and seldom wear them because they are too warm for me.  So what options are there that are comfortable and inexpensive for women like me that have one large breast.  It sounds like a lot of the women posting were rather small to start with or something and a loose top was all it took to disguise the difference.  Don't think that will work for me. Dx 3/5/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 2/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: lopsided haykat57 starzhere

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 08:54PM haykat57 wrote: Wallycat, Did you do the radiation or skip it since you were having the masectomy?  I'm sure I can get these answers from my doctors, but I'm a little worried about another surgery so soon.  I had a surgical biopsy two weeks ago and now the lumpectomy.  If I have the masectomy I don't know how long I can safely go without radiation before having the masectomy.  So far they are saying that I don't have to have chemo, but I am getting a second opinion on that.  I was all set to do a masectomy until I had three different doctors tell me that all I needed was a lumpectomy.  These are hard choices to make, I appreciate the personal accounts on this web site to help get an insight into how I will feel.  That is one thing the doctors are as good at understanding.
Posts.Title: lumpectomy regrets haykat57 Merle

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2008 03:55PM haykat57 wrote: Gwen,  so sorry to hear about your pet.  At least he was with you to the end of your treatments.  It has been reassuring to hear that no one was instructed to farm out their animals during treatment, so I don't expect my doctor will instruct me to do so.  DH has already taken over the duties of caring for them and I am already practicing washing my hands all the time.  I have always had a very healthy immune system so have never had to worry a lot about infection, this will take  some discipline.  thanks everyone for all the input. haykat
Posts.Title: pets and chemo haykat57 mittmott

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2008 09:57AM haykat57 wrote: Thursday I meet with my surgeon and also a plastic surgeon.  Friday I am supposed to meet with the radiation oncologist to begin radiation therapy.  I am expecting to go with the mammosite radiation that only takes 5 days and does less damage to the surrounding tissue.  It is hard to tell how mis-shapen I will be ultimately, because at the moment I have a spacer inserted that helps fill out the breast.  I spoke to a friend at work earlier, who told me she had a third of her right breast removed several years ago and that she doesn't use a prosthesis, but it isn't noticeable.  That was encouraging since obviously I hadn't ever noticed a difference.  I have always hated wearing bras to start with and the thought of not only having to wear one to look normal, but adding even more contraptions makes me mad.  I am definitely considering breast reduction of my unaffected breast as an option and it looks like my supplemental insurance plan will cover it.  Thanks for all the comments, they have helped a lot.
Posts.Title: lumpectomy regrets haykat57 Merle

Posts.Content: haykat57 wrote: Well, Friday I had a lumpectomy because my surgeon, and my medical and radiation oncologists all said that a masectomy wasn't necessary.  I liked the idea of not having to take as long to recover or worry about reconstruction.  After the surgery and before the swelling started my breast was half the size of the other and sadly mis-shapen.  That leaves me with the option of reconstruction, a prosthetic or looking like a freak.  So no real gain, but now I have to have radiation, which I wouldn't have needed if I had just gone ahead with the masectomy.  It is so hard to know how to make the right decisions in the first place.  It would have been nice if my surgeon would have let me know that this was a possibility.  She presented it like just a minimal inconvenience.  She is a good and compassionate surgeon, but I think she looks too much on the bright side in order not to upset me.  So, what are my options?  Am I missing anything? Dx 3/5/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 2/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: lumpectomy regrets haykat57 Merle

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 02:22PM haykat57 wrote: I'm thinking of making the good one smaller to match, but I will have to see what my insurance covers.
Posts.Title: lumpectomy regrets haykat57 Merle

Posts.Content: haykat57 wrote: I'm wondering if anyone knows anything about having pets in the house during chemo.  I have two cats.  Both pretty gentle.  Dh has already said he will do the litter box routine, but will that be enough? Dx 3/5/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 2/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: pets and chemo haykat57 mittmott

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 12:43PM haykat57 wrote: Randie, I read your post about having a prophylactic mast and I am considering the same thing.  I never want to go through this again.  My dh's mother and my first husband's mother both had breast cancer and both had it second time in the remaining breast about 15 years later.  This is hard enough at 50, I don't want to deal with it at 65.  My dh is definitely a boob man, but he loves me more than he loves my parts.  I still have to figure out the insurance issue.  It will only be about another thousand dollars to have a double masectomy as opposed to a single which we can afford.  However, the reconstruction I want is ten thousand per breast.  My insurance will pay for one, but may not pay for the other.  So I've been joking with friends about doing a fund raiser, "Buy a Boob for Kathy"  They laugh, but say they'll support it.  I also had a question about the pills you are taking before tx.  I start Taxol on Monday and my doctor has given me an rx for Ibuprofen and my nurses have suggested the B6 and B complex vitamins, but what are you taking?  I read a post about icing feet and hands during infusion to reduce neuropathy which makes sense to me since they had me suck on ice cubes with my other infusions to diminish the effects on my mouth from those drugs.  About your ovaries, I am considering having mine out also, just because some of the drugs increase the risk of ovarian cancer which is hard to detect, but your dr will probably still want you on an arimatse inhibitor because your body still produces some estrogen.  I know how you feel about not wanting to put anything more in your body though, I hate that part too.  I was one who would rather take an ice pack to bed with a headache than to take an aspirin. Kathy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2008 04:50PM haykat57 wrote: Debbie, the family history of breast cancer is through my husband, so I don't think the insurance company will take that into account.  Too bad, though.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 12:55AM haykat57 wrote: Otter, good to hear from you, hope your treatments are going well.  I spent some time on the alternative sights because I was so on the fence about doing this.  This last onc was able to convince me this was a good route to go.  He is much more understanding about my concerns.  I am going to try and minimize the side affects through nutrition and exercise, but my husband said if I didn't do the chemo and I died he would be a very angry man and I figured if I DID do the chemo and I died I would be in heaven and really wouldn't care!!  Better not to leave and angry man behind.  It doesn't help that my mother died from the side effects of her chemo and not the cancer.  I will be much more cooperative and proactive about my care than she was which is why I had to find the right doctor that I felt I could trust.  I will try to pop over to the April site from time to time to see how you are all doing. Kat
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 09:02PM haykat57 wrote: Good morning ladies. Well, I'm up and feeling better.  Most of the bone pain is gone, I hope it stays that way.  My onco nurse said only Tylenol, not to take Alleve, but I'm not sure about Advil.  I don't usually need pain medication and when I do it is usually Alleve or Tylenol.  Is Advil an NSAID like Alleve?  Now I'm running a fever of about 2 degrees, so I guess I will call my doctor before I leave.  I have felt fine, with only some fatigue and a couple of bouts of nausea (mostly from poor planning), so I didn't think there would be a problem planning this trip. I'm supposed to go back to work tomorrow, too.  This is not working as I planned. {?*&@!!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 12:22AM haykat57 wrote: Well, I thought I would be starting chemo in April and started a thread to that affect, but here I am in May.  Had my first round of FEC on the 8th.   Went through 3 oncologists before choosing one.  I had one who was very compassionate, but her staff was too overwhelmed and kept making mistakes with my charts and appointments.  The next guy was so autocratic he would barely listen to my concerns let alone discuss them with me.  Finally went with a doctor recommended by an aquaintance who had recently finished chemo for breast cancer.  Glad I checked him out.  I was almost ready to skip the whole chemo scene and go with alternative therapies because I was so concerned about the long term side affects of this stuff.  I have a cousin who went that route 5 years ago who is still here and her cancer was staged almost the same as mine and she only did the lumpectomy and AND same as me. So far the side effects have been minimmal.  A couple of bad spells of nausea with profuse sweaty on the first day, but soon learned not to let my stomach get too empty or too full.  Lots of energy the first two days, but fatigue really kicked in on the third.  Went to Curves the first day of chemo and participated in the relay for life event the next night.  Lots of wonderful support from the community.  When they were calling off the names of cancer survivors and victims my husband was leaning over to say how God knows all those names by heart just at the moment they called my name.  What a special moment.  Made a new friend and ally with our new manager that night.  It turns out he lost his first wife only two years ago to breast cancer.  He was very tender towards my husband and I, so I feel much more secure at work now since my direct supervisor has been somewhat of a problem through all of this.  So today is starting out good, this is the first morning my stomach hasn't woke me up to tell me feed it or else.  Only taking one anti-nausea med today and may not need it much more.  So far, so good.  I'll take some time to read the other postings to get to know who my chemo buddies are. Kat
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 01:14PM haykat57 wrote: Hey, anyone still up?  I had to have a shot of neupogen and procrit today and boy am I achy now.  Dr. said no nsaids, only tylenol, but it isn't cutting it.  Any suggestions?  How long will this last?  I'm supposed to make a road trip with my son tomorrow and I'm not sure I can do it if I hurt like this all day.  I also read about the shingles that danismom had and I have a similar condition that flares up on my tailbone and forgot to mention it to the doctor today.  I'm starting to get a flare up.  Tomorrow may end up a lot different than planned.  Any advise would help.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: haykat57 wrote: Well, I am still waiting for good news.  Going in Friday for my third surgery in 4 weeks.  Bumped up to stage II.  Two of four lymph nodes came back positive from the lumpectomy.  More lymph nodes will be removed and a port put in for chemo.  Tomorrow I meet with a new medical oncologist.  Everyone with any cancer experience in this area has said he is the best.  Really feeling down about the new path reports.  Still haven't had any scans, will probably have some scheduled next week.  I guess the good news is that my surgeon really seems to have some clout and is able to get me in to see other specialists quickly.  So, anyone else starting chemo soon? Dx 3/5/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 2/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 07:41AM haykat57 wrote: Nancy, when you are feeling up to it could you let me know what your tx schedule is?  My onc wants to do 4XAC 3 weeks apart and then 12XTaxol for 12 wks.  So it would be the same drugs as you, but different schedule.  I meet with him next Wed., but want to find out if I could do all three together for 12 wks to shorten my tx time.  I risk loosing my position at work if I take too much time off, but if I am doing it all at once I could just take the whole 3 months off and not work at all which would make it easier to deal with and less likely to impact my position at work.  Since I see that you and others are doing all three drugs at once, I am just wondering if it is because your has you taking it for a shorter perior or something. Thanks, Kathy

Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 02:00AM haykat57 wrote: Well it looks like I will be going through chemo with a great group of women.  Came through the surgery Friday okay, my surgeon did a great job with all the incisions and making my boob look normal.  The port is a bit uncomfortable, but getting better.  Had the drain out on Tuesday, but it had a clot so she said I might have some fluid build up, but nothing much so far.  The best part is that there was no more cancer in the nodes she took out. Yeah!! Angie27- I've read some of your threads here and elsewhere and hope you are feeling better.  I am not so much scared as I am mad.  Even with the cancer I feel healthy, but now I have to get sick to stay that way.  And all the side effects!  I am glad to see from the other postings that I am not the only one who wishes she didn't have to go this route.  Before they found the cancer in the lymph nodes they were only talking about the Tamoxifen and I didn't even want that.  Reading through "tips to get through chemo" on another thread helped me feel more in control and more optimistic about all this.  Here is one tip that might help those with nausea.  When I was pregnant with my daughter I had morning sickness anytime I was around food for seven months.  The one food that would always go down and stay down was oatmeal.  I hated the whole dry cracker bit.  Getting my dh to bring me some oatmeal in bed helped start the day off without a pit stop at the commode.  Figure I'll give it a try this time too.  Don't have a start date yet, but have a PET scan on the 9th and appt with onc on the 16th so I expect to start the next week. We'll get through this together.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2008 06:10PM haykat57 wrote: Angie, I'm really sorry that you are so anxious.  I haven't started my chemo yet, but I took care of my mother when she did her chemo for lung cancer and I can tell you that the one thing I am hearing from the other postings and from the experience I had with my mother is that as long as you take the meds for the side effects you should be fine.  My mother was stubborn and wouldn't take her anti-constipation meds and that caused considerable problems.  The infusions were relatively uneventful and I believe all the side effects she suffered were from not having bowel movements.  The one thing I tell people about that experience was that half the meds she was taking were to counteract the side effects of the other meds.  But if that is what it takes then I am going with the program.  Just stay focused on the fact that this won't last forever. My surgeon from the start has said that by the holidays all of this should be behind me.  It's not what I planned for this year, but the holidays will be that much sweeter.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 03:55PM haykat57 wrote: Otter, I agree with the others, you have shown a lot of strength through all of this, but we are all different.  Me, I intend to laugh my way through this.  I've been joking about getting a tattoo and actually found a site where I can get temporary ones specially made for chemo patients.  But that won't help you.  I found an ad for wigs that has one like you described you were looking for. They are only $29 and have a money back guarantee so you could try a couple rather inexpensively.  Their website is thewigcompany.com.  I know what you mean about the wig sales associate wanting them all to look like her hairstyle.  I had long straight hair until I got in high school and decided to try something new.  I wanted a nice shoulder length bob and even had a friend come with me who had a hair cut like what I wanted.  I ended up with a page boy cut that looked hideous on me, but which was exactly the type of hairstyle the beautician had.  I hope you find something that you can feel good about.  Me, I just hate putting all this junk in my system, I'm not a total health nut, but I always read labels and avoid chemicals as much as is economically possible.  But like I said, we are all different.  Kathy

Posts.Content: haykat57 wrote: Well, I am still waiting for good news.  Going in Friday for my third surgery in 4 weeks.  Bumped up to stage II.  Two of four lymph nodes came back positive from the lumpectomy.  More lymph nodes will be removed and a port put in for chemo.  Tomorrow I meet with a new medical oncologist.  Everyone with any cancer experience in this area has said he is the best.  Really feeling down about the new path reports.  Still haven't had any scans, will probably have some scheduled next week.  I guess the good news is that my surgeon really seems to have some clout and is able to get me in to see other specialists quickly.  So, anyone else starting chemo soon? Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 08:58AM haykat57 wrote: Ruth, when I started down this journey my onc said I probably would not have to do chemo because they figured they caught it early enough that it hadn't gotten into the lymph nodes.  I had the port in for mammosite radiation and everything and then two nodes came back positive.  So, port came out and we went back in for more nodes, all negative fortunately.  So, it seems that with your diagnoses it is pretty standard to just go with the tamoxifen for five years and skip the heavy artillery.  Have you had any scans done, just to make sure? There are long term side effects to the chemo, that had I been given the option you have I would have taken it, but peace of mind is worth a lot, too.  My mother-in-law had breast cancer over 20 years ago with no chemo and she is still around, although there was a recurrence in the other breast 13 years ago.  With the Tamoxifen that they give now, she probably would not have had that recurrence.  Hope you are able to make a decision that you are comfortable with. Kathy
Posts.Title: Should I have cehmo? RuthL tiff2008
